results.title: Reinventing Japan
results.creator_credit: Alex Gibney, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Pacific century”.
This program looks at the peculiar relationship between Japan and the United States that emerged in the wake of World War II. Set to the tunes of big band jazz and including footage of the period never before seen, “Reinventing Japan” captures the spirit of a strange era, full of idealism and democracy as well as bitter betrayals, when one country tried to reinvent another in its image - with surprising and unexpected results.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Gibney, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions

results.title: Writers & revolutionaries
results.creator_credit: Steve Talley, Alex Gibney, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Pacific century”.
Revolutions often arise from the writings of men of ideas. This program looks at the crucial influence of Lu Xun and Kita Ikki on the Chinese revolution and the revolutionary transformation of Japan into a dominant military and economic power. Lu Xun set out to destroy traditional Chinese culture which he saw as backward, corrupt and complacent and became the greatest Chinese author of the 20th century and a major influence on Mao. Kita Ikki, by contrast sought a return to a pure and traditional spirit of nationalism which led to Japan’s imperialism prior to World War II. Rare archival footage, some of which is very distressing, enhances this fascinating program. A study guide and faculty manual is also available.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Talley, Alex Gibney, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions

Kita Ikki, by contrast sought a return to a pure and traditional spirit of nationalism which led to Japan’s imperialism prior to World War II. Rare archival footage, some of which is very distressing, enhances this fascinating program. A study guide and faculty manual is also available.

results.title: From the barrel of a gun
results.creator_credit: Steven Talley, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Pacific century”.
This video looks at how two men - Ho Chi Minh and Sukharno destroyed the myth of western supremacy by tapping into the innate spirit of nationalism which had been repressed in the peoples of Vietnam and Indonesia. The video mixes archival footage, eyewitness accounts and expert commentary to show the roots of the Vietnamese war and the rise of Indonesia as a political power.

results.title: The Pacific century. Study guide
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Pacific century”.
To accompany The Pacific century telecourse. The purpose of The Study guide is to aid students in their study of the telecourse material. Included are: an overview, identification of study resources, study focus statements, a listing of key concepts and names, a glossary, time-frame questions, questions for review and additional recommended readings.

results.title: Making open hearth steel
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare, British Iron and Steel Federation and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
Chemical reactions by which steel is refined from iron and steel scrap are explained by animated sequences. The function of slag and the differences between acid and basic furnaces are also outlined.

results.title: How it works
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
An explanation of how the furnace is constructed to withstand the very high temperatures needed to make steel. The system of regeneration by which gas and air are heated before being burned in the furnace is also illustrated.

results.title: At the brink
results.creator_credit: Peter Raymont, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
In an exclusive interview, former Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko speaks for the first time about his famous White House Meeting with President Kennedy at the height of the Cuban Missile Crisis, and refutes certain claims made at the time. “…Kennedy never raised the question of the presence of Soviet missiles in Cuba. I repeat, he never mentioned it.” The statesman recalled that the discussions were “full of sharp turns.” For the first time since the end of the Second World War, the Cuban Missile crisis brought the world to the brink of a Nuclear war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Raymont, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)

I repeat, he never mentioned it.” The statesman recalled that the discussions were “full of sharp turns.” For the first time since the end of the Second World War, the Cuban Missile crisis brought the world to the brink of a Nuclear war.
